awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Measuring Variation in Water Pollution Impacts and Water Insecurity Infrastructures Across Socioeconomic Status
awd_abstract_narration:
While research has consistently shown how poorer communities as an aggregate tend to bear with the most of negative consequences associated with environmental pollution, less is understood about whether pollution from a common environmental source is differentially experienced along class lines, and if so, to what extent. This research takes place in an urban landscape where both middle- and lower- class residents are impacted by water pollution. The project would train a graduate student in scientific cultural anthropology and its results would be disseminated to academic and non-academic audiences. The project also broadens the participation of historically underrepresented groups in the production of scientific knowledge. The findings will be disseminated to the broader public through public media channels and a photovoice exhibit, as well as non-academic reports to the main stakeholders involved in the study.

This project examines perceptions of environmental pollution by measuring variation across a comparative sample of upper-class, gated communities, and informal settlements where lower-income residents live. It also investigates the infrastructures, tools, and behavioral mechanisms enacted by different social groups and individuals to understand the complexities of human-environment interaction. Comparative in nature, this research employs conventional ethnographic methods like semi-structured interviews and participant observation, as well as nontraditional techniques such as walking interviews and photovoice. The project makes important contributions to urban political ecology, theories of water insecurity, and environmental studies and inequality broadly within the fields of geography and anthropology.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Water sustains life, yet 44% of global household wastewater is discharged into water bodies without proper treatment, leading to waterborne diseases, environmental disequilibrium, and complex challenges in remediation. While contamination disproportionately affects lower-income communities, exposure to polluted water bodies is not exclusive to them. Researchers have documented the lived experiences of marginalized groups facing water and environmental issues. However, this study broadens the scope by systematically examining both upper-class gated communities and lower-income favelas (informal settlements) as they navigate shared yet unequal exposure to polluted canals and lagoons. Beyond highlighting injustices, this research reveals shared class struggles, strategies developed to address them, and the unexpected cultural traits that emerge from living in an environmentally damaged landscape.

I spent 20 months (2022–2024) conducting fieldwork in Recreio dos Bandeirantes, a wealthy beachfront neighborhood in Rio de Janeiro, Brazil. Within this privileged setting, a favela sits just a few hundred feet from the beach, yet it is also in proximity to a contaminated canal and lagoon. Unlike formal zones, these areas lack marginal vegetation, exacerbating residents' exposure to pollution. This site is particularly productive as it serves as a microcosm for investigating class-based environmental struggles within local and global contexts of inequality. During fieldwork, I conducted 40 semi-structured interviews with residents from both formal and informal areas, as well as municipal government workers from the Secretary of Environment, the Secretary of Urban Planning, and the Stormwater Office. The interviews explore class-based experiences and perceptions of environmental contamination, along with the challenges and strategies employed by residents, community leaders, and government agencies to address pollution. Additionally, I conducted archival research at the National Library and the National Archives of Brazil, uncovering novel documents that contextualize the impacts of water drainage infrastructure projects on land use and urban expansion. Furthermore, I implemented photovoice, a community-based participatory research method that empowers participants to document their lived experiences through photography. I recruited eight residents from both gated communities and favelas, fostering interclass and intergenerational collaboration through the photographic process as they shared their stories, struggles, and aspirations. With support from Rio’s Secretary of Environment, we showcased a Photovoice Exhibit and held presentations at the Municipal Park Chico Mendes and in three local public schools, displaying the images and stories produced by the collaborators. According to estimates from the park’s manager and school principals, over 2,000 people, including students, visitors, activists, and policymakers, engaged with the exhibit.

In terms of intellectual merit, this project contributes to the social sciences by engaging in theoretical dialogues within both cultural anthropology and human geography. Three key threads of thought guide the significance of this research. First, I engage with environmental history by connecting environmental imaginaries with the long-term consequences of water infrastructure projects driven by public health narratives. Second, I contribute to environmental anthropology by examining the lived experiences and perceptions of lagoon and canal contamination, as well as access to water, in light of the material and infrastructural realities of an unequal urban landscape. Lastly, by drawing on the epistemological flexibility of the anthropology of water, I have identified unexpected forms of cultural manifestation—apparent in music, art, fashion, behavior, and politics—that emerge from the proximity between people and the animals of this impacted ecosystem.

Some of the broader impacts of this research have already taken place, while others will unfold through dissertation writing and dissemination. I have presented preliminary findings at two conferences in Brazil and one symposium at the University of Georgia, Athens. Documents resulting from archival work have been shared with government workers, expanding their database on water infrastructure in the field site. Furthermore, I implemented photovoice, engaging closely with research collaborators in the knowledge-making process. The photovoice exhibit reached more than 2,000 individuals, providing an opportunity for people to learn and engage in dialogues about both the positive and negative aspects of the neighborhood. This event was highly valued by collaborators and spectators, who felt empowered by their participation in the project and by seeing familiar places displayed through art and photography. In the future, I will produce peer-reviewed articles and policy briefs and present my findings at anthropological and interdisciplinary conferences in the United States and abroad.
